productInfo.name: Matcha
productInfo.desc: The KTT Matcha is one of our favorite expressions of a tactile switch. We detect a comfortable, snappy tactility when typing on them. Plus, look forward to a distinctly clean bottom-out sound due to its long pole stem.

productInfo.name: Phalaenopsis
productInfo.desc: With the beautiful translucent Phalaenopsis switchesâ€“which feature a light actuation force of 37gâ€“typing becomes effortless and finger fatigue is minimized even during prolonged typing sessions. The 50g tactile force provides a satisfying and discernible tactile bump, ensuring each keystroke is a delightful experience.

productInfo.name: Strawberry
productInfo.desc: These delectable Strawberriesâ€”with their attractive pink and clear housingsâ€”are loved for their smooth actuation, comfortable feel, and reliable performance.

productInfo.name: Cabbage Tofu
productInfo.desc: Introducing the Cabbage Tofu switch which offers improved tactility and responsiveness. Due to its lengthened 22mm spring, typists will notice a swift rebound after actuation, allowing for a quicker transition between keystrokes. When using them, we find a sound profile reminiscent of Mahjong tiles colliding.

productInfo.name: Grapefruit
productInfo.desc: These KTT Grapefruit switches are special. These tarty linear switches showcase a soft and light type feel, along with a "baritone" though not yet "bass" deep sound profile.

productInfo.name: Peach
productInfo.desc: These Peach switches feature multiple prized characteristics of a linear switch. Expect a syrupy smooth typing experience and a deep, thocky sound profile.

productInfo.name: Rose
productInfo.desc: As beautiful as these Rose switches are, there are more than what meets the eye here. The use of progressive springs here offers a uniquely substantial, yet not heavy, typing experience. We hear bassy raindrops when typing on these switches.

productInfo.name: Pine
productInfo.desc: Meet the translucent, forest green KTT Pine Linear Switches: medium-heavy, buttery smooth, and built for an effortless typing experience. Thanks to a polished, factory-lubed finish, these switches minimize friction for smooth key travel.

productInfo.name: Orange
productInfo.desc: The KTT Orange Switches come with a 22mm long spring for a bouncy type feel. Featuring a polycarbonate milky top housing, long pole POM stem, and a vivid orange nylon bottom housing, these switches provide a slick, frictionless typing experience and a low-pitched sound profile. Moreover, thanks to its excellent factory-lubing, you can count on a refined, fluid key travel that minimizes friction and maximizes smoothness.

productInfo.name: Cream Yellow
productInfo.desc: The Cream Yellow switch is designed to deliver a distinctively clacky sound: its shortened bottom-out distance and long-pole stem provides resonant audio feedback. Its lengthened spring also contributes to a uniquely bouncy typing feel.

productInfo.name: Semi Mute
productInfo.desc: Named "Semi Mute" despite their completely silent operation, these switches are tailor-made for those who value a noise-free environment and desire undisturbed typing, especially during late-night sessions. Featuring a linear actuation and advanced dampening technology, the KTT Semi Mute switches provide a comfortable and gratifying typing feel.

productInfo.name: Laurel
productInfo.desc: Discover the KTT Laurel, a medium-light linear switch. With its full POM housing, short travel, and long pole design, this switch strikes the perfect balance of responsiveness and comfort. Moreover, we find a subtly low-pitched sound profile with the KTT Laurel switch.

productInfo.name: Ash Gray
productInfo.desc: Designed to deliver a tactile response that's substantial yet unobtrusive, the Ash Gray switch masterfully combines a light touch with a crisp actuation. On your fingertips, you'll encounter a delightful blend of tactile feedbackâ€“not too overwhelming, yet far from the unnoticed â€œsandyâ€ sensation.

productInfo.name: Hyacinth
productInfo.desc: While using a familiar combo of materials, the Hyacinth switches stand out for its design choice of a 3.5mm travel distance. This design decision was made to avoid the hard bottoming-out experience that's common with switches with longer stems; a decision driven by a commitment to create an ideal balance between tactile feedback, auditory experience, and user comfort. Moreover, the KTT Hyacinth deviates from the mainstream trend of using dual-stage elongated springs, instead opting for a single-stage elongated spring. This choice was driven by a preference for a more consistent force curve.

productInfo.name: Glimp
productInfo.desc: Introducing the Glimp switch, a medium-light switch that strikes the perfect balance for those seeking a substantial typing experience without overwhelming resistance. With its tactile feedback and comfortable actuation force, the Glimp switch offers a satisfying and responsive typing feel. Additionally, its fairly clacky sound profile adds an enjoyable auditory element to your typing sessions.

productInfo.name: Mannan Pipefish
productInfo.desc: Experience effortless and enjoyable typing with the Mannan Pipefish switch. Its smooth linear action, lengthened spring, and light 45g actuation and bottom-out force provide a comfortable and precise typing experience. Perfect for casual typists seeking a delightful and strain-free keyboarding journey.

productInfo.name: Wine Red
productInfo.desc: We love these intoxicating Wine Red switches. When typing on them, we find a pillowy light type feel along with a satisfyingly deep and rich sound profile.

productInfo.name: Sea Salt Lemon
productInfo.desc: These Sea Salt Lemons are a lovely representation of what a linear switch can be. Its progressive spring and KTT's dry-lube design lend these switches a buttery smooth typing experience.

productInfo.name: Mint
productInfo.desc: We love this satisfyingly smooth linear switch. Due to its long pole stem, when typing on them, we experience a poppy thockiness. Moreover, expect a light and fleeting type feel.

productInfo.name: Kang White
productInfo.desc: This switch is an exquisite representation of a poppy linear switchâ€”the typing sound is dazzling. In addition, because of its self-lubricating material, we find an unparalleled smoothness when typing on them.

productInfo.name: Lightning
productInfo.desc: The KTT Lightnings are very approachable "speed" switches: they are perfect switches for when milliseconds can decide whether you win or lose. When typing on them, we find a slick type feel with a clacky sound profile.

productInfo.name: Purple Click
productInfo.desc: The Purple Click (also known as Purple Sauce) switchâ€™s signature attribute is a fairly high-pitched, satisfying click. The keystrokes are light, yet offer a tactility that is pronounced without being overwhelming; in other words, a perfect equilibrium.

questions_and_answers.question: What are KTT switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: KTT is a manufacturer of mechanical keyboard switches. KTT switches are popular among gamers and enthusiasts for their precision and responsiveness. They are also commonly used in office environments for their durability and reliability. Moreover, KTT switches come in a wide spectrum of colors. As such, if you are selective about your switches from an aesthetic point of view, KTT switches are a great place to discover the best switch that suit your aesthetic sensibilities.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Kailh switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Kailh switches are switches manufactured by Kailh. In particular, Kailhâ€™s clicky offerings are some of the most popular among keyboard enthusiasts who prefer a crunchy sound profile and a tactile typing experience.

questions_and_answers.question: Are Kailh switches good?
questions_and_answers.answer: Kailh switches are great. They are particularly known for their clicky switches such as the Box White, as well as being the manufacturer behind the popular NovelKeysâ€™ Cream linear switches.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Cherry switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Cherry switches are the most well-known switches available today. Part of this is due to history, as Cherry is the original switch manufacturer. However, the fact that people still buy Cherry switches today goes to show the timelessness of the original lineup of the Cherry MX switches: these switches still carry their weight today.

questions_and_answers.question: Are Cherry switches the best?
questions_and_answers.answer: Cherry switches are the industry standard. However, there are many switches on the market available today by many excellent manufacturers. You should instead try many switches to find the one that suits you the best.

questions_and_answers.question: Why are Cherry switches popular?
questions_and_answers.answer: Cherry has great name recognition within the keyboard community. Their switches are classics for a reason: for many, the sound and feel of Cherry MX switches are timeless and cannot be displaced by modern switches.

questions_and_answers.question: What are KTT switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: KTT is a manufacturer of mechanical keyboard switches. KTT switches are popular among gamers and enthusiasts for their precision and responsiveness. They are also commonly used in office environments for their durability and reliability. Moreover, KTT switches come in a wide spectrum of colors. As such, if you are selective about your switches from an aesthetic point of view, KTT switches are a great place to discover the best switch that suit your aesthetic sensibilities.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Durock switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Durock switches are switches manufactured by Durock. Durock designs and manufactures some of the best linear and tactile switches on the market today.

questions_and_answers.question: Are Durock switches good?
questions_and_answers.answer: Durock switches have become one of the most popular switches todayâ€”and for good reason. Durockâ€™s T1 tactile switches, known for their rounded tactile bump, are one of the most well-loved tactile switch options today.

questions_and_answers.question: Are Durock switches good for gaming?
questions_and_answers.answer: Yes, Durock switches work well for gaming. Gamers use both Durockâ€™s linear and tactile switches and love them for their tactile bump and smooth keystrokes, respectively.

questions_and_answers.question: Is Durock the same as JWK?
questions_and_answers.answer: Durock is directly related to JWK. You can think of Durock as the manufacturer behind JWK, which is the brand. Because JWK switches are manufactured by Durock, this has led to some ambiguity about terminology within the keyboard community.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the connection between Jwick and Durock?
questions_and_answers.answer: Durock and Jwick are two brands of switches made by the same manufacturer. You can think of the connection between the two brands as that of Nike and Jordans: different brands, same manufacturer.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Everglide switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Everglide switches are switches created by Everglide. They are known for making some of the best linear switches on the market today and are revered for their smoothness.

questions_and_answers.question: What are SP Star switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: SP Star switches are switches created by SP Star. They are known for making some of the best linear switches on the market today and are revered for their smoothness.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Gateron switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Gateron switches are switches created by Gateron. They are known for making some of the best linear switches on the market today and are revered for their smoothness.

questions_and_answers.question: Are Gateron switches good?
questions_and_answers.answer: Gateron switches make for some of the best on the market today. Gateron switches such as the Gateron Oil King, as well as all the switches in their Ink lineup are beloved by the community for their silky smoothness.

questions_and_answers.question: Which Gateron switches are the best?
questions_and_answers.answer: The best switch depends on personal preference. However, if you are looking for a silky smooth switch, then we strongly recommend Gateronâ€™s Oil Kings.

questions_and_answers.question: What's the quietest Gateron switch?
questions_and_answers.answer: The Gateron Silent Ink Black is the quietest Gateron switch.

questions_and_answers.question: How long do Gateron switches last?
questions_and_answers.answer: Gateron switches last for at least 50 million keystrokes. For reference, mechanical keyboards from the 1980s and 1990s are still working great today, decades after their manufacturing.  In other words, a very, very long time.

questions_and_answers.question: Which Gateron switch is best for gaming?
questions_and_answers.answer: The best switch for gaming depends on personal preference. However, if you are looking for an in-game typing experience characterized by smoothness, then the Gateron Oil Kings are a great choice.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Outemu switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Outemu offers a wide range of switches, including linear, tactile, and clicky options. Outemu switches come in a variety of colors and actuation forces. In addition, they are known for manufacturing Gazzew's switches.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Wuque Studio switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Wuque Studio (WS) is a brand which designs switches. Wuque Studio's various offerings has recently gained traction in the community for their smoothness. They have partnered with JWK and Haimu to manufacture their switches; they do not engage in switch manufacturing themselves.

questions_and_answers.question: What are TTC switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: TTC switches are known for their smoothness as well as their durability and reliability. TTC mechanical keyboard switches are made from high-quality materials, which helps to ensure that they last a long time and provide a consistent and satisfying typing experience. Some people prefer TTC switches for their quiet operation, while others appreciate the smooth and consistent actuation that these switches provide. Overall, TTC mechanical keyboard switches are a popular choice among many keyboard enthusiasts.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Jwick switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Jwick (JWK) is a company that makes high quality switches. Their switches are known to be some of the smoothest available today.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the connection between Jwick and Durock?
questions_and_answers.answer: Jwick and Durock are two brands of switches made by the same manufacturer. You can think of the connection between the two brands as that of Nike and Jordans: different brands, same manufacturer.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Aflion switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Aflion is a relatively new switch manufacturer. Aflion's switches tend to have thicker housings. Moreover, Aflion's switches are smooth and offer a very satisfying level of clack. Aflion's switches offer users a pleasing typing experience, both in terms of sound and feel.

questions_and_answers.question: What are Haimu switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Haimu is a switch manufacturer mainly known for its partnerships with other switch designers (i.e. they don't release many switches under their own name). In particular, they are known for their silent switches since they do not opt to use the rubber dampening method prevalent in most other silent switches. Instead, they opt for cut-outs, which remove the rubbery bottom-out feel that comes with most silent switches.

questions_and_answers.question: What are TKC switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: TKC (The Key Company) does many things, one of which is designing switches. TKC's various offerings has gained traction in the community, namely their linear Tangerine switches.

Gazzew switches are a lineup of mechanical switches designed by Gazzew. They are known for their smoothness, unique stem design, and customization options. Gazzew switches come in different variants, including tactile, linear, and silent options.
questions_and_answers.question: What are Gazzew switches?

questions_and_answers.answer: Gazzew switches come in several variants, including the U4 (silent tactile), U4T (thocky tactile), U4Tx (half-thocky tactile), LT (linear thock), and Bobagum (silent linear).
questions_and_answers.question: What are the different variants of Gazzew switches?

questions_and_answers.answer: Gazzew switches, depending on variety, have a tactile bump or linear feel depending on the variant. The linear variants include the Bobagum and LT. The tactile variants include the U4, U4T, and U4Tx. Gazzew switches are also popular among keyboard enthusiasts for their customization options, high quality, and tight tolerances.
questions_and_answers.question: What makes Gazzew switches unique?

questions_and_answers.answer: Gazzew switches are highly regarded within the mechanical keyboard community. They are often compared to other popular switches like Cherry MX and Gateron. Gazzew switches are known for their smoothness, tight tolerances, and customizable options, making them a favorite among enthusiasts.
questions_and_answers.question: How do Gazzew switches compare to other popular switches?

questions_and_answers.answer: Outemu is the manufacturer of Gazzew switches.
questions_and_answers.question: Who manufactures Gazzew switches?

types.desc: Tactile switches have a satisfying tactile bump and sound either clacky or thocky

questions_and_answers.question: What is a tactile switch?
questions_and_answers.answer: Tactile switches are a type of switch that offer users a tactile bump when pressing down and have a relatively subdued sound profile.

questions_and_answers.question: What are tactile switches good for?
questions_and_answers.answer: Tactile switches are good for many use cases: they are an excellent all-rounder. Tactile switches are good for gaming because of the the tactile bump you feel when pressing down. Tactile switches can be good for office work and noise-sensitive environments because they are relatively quiet. Other users like it for its tactility and clacky or thocky sound profile.

questions_and_answers.question: Are tactile switches better?
questions_and_answers.answer: Ultimately, the best switch for you comes down to personal preference. But if you are looking for a typing experience characterized by tactility with a subdued sound profile, then tactile switches are for you.

questions_and_answers.question: Do tactile switches feel weird?
questions_and_answers.answer: Tactile switches should not feel weird: they are known for their tactile bump. However, if you prefer more smoothness when typing, consider linear switches.

questions_and_answers.question: Can you type fast with tactile switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: You can type fast with tactile switches as with any other switch varieties. Once you get accustomed to a switch style, you can type fast on it.

questions_and_answers.question: Are all tactile switches good for gaming?
questions_and_answers.answer: Tactile switches are great for gaming. Gamers love tactile switches for their tactility, which offers them feedback in their keystrokes.

questions_and_answers.question: Why do gamers use tactile switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Gamers use tactile switches for the feedback â€œbumpâ€ they get when pressing on keys.

questions_and_answers.question: Are tactile switches mechanical?
questions_and_answers.answer: Tactile switches are one variety of mechanical switches known for their keystrokes with tactile bumps. Contrast this to linear mechanical switches, which do not have that bump and are instead smooth.

big_picture.desc: have a bump that gives you physical feedback when pressing down
depending on switch, a subtle or sharp bump
ranges from silent to a gentle clack or thock
of the tangible feedback you get when activating a key; suitable for noise-sensitive environments

types.desc: Clicky switches have audible clicks and tactile bumps while typing on them

questions_and_answers.question: What is a clicky switch?
questions_and_answers.answer: Clicky switches are a type of switch that offer users a tactile bump when pressing down and have a signature loud â€œclicky-clackâ€ sound profile.

questions_and_answers.question: What are clicky switches good for?
questions_and_answers.answer: Clicky switches are great for their tactile feedback in their keystrokes and their signature pronounced crunchy sound signature. Clicky switches are best for personal environments such as for your gaming setup or home-office due to its sound profile.

questions_and_answers.question: Are clicky switches better?
questions_and_answers.answer: Ultimately, the best switch for you comes down to personal preference. But if you are looking for a tactile typing experience with a loud and crunchy sound profile, then clicky switches are for you.

questions_and_answers.question: Do clicky switches feel weird?
questions_and_answers.answer: Clicky switches should not feel weird: they have a tactile bump. However, if you prefer a smoother typing experience, consider linear switches.

questions_and_answers.question: Can you type fast with clicky switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: You can type fast with clicky switches as with any other switch varieties. Once you get accustomed to a switch style, you can type fast on it.

questions_and_answers.question: Are all clicky switches good for gaming?
questions_and_answers.answer: Clicky switches are great for gaming. Gamers love clicky switches for their sound profile and tactile feedback.

questions_and_answers.question: Why do gamers use clicky switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Gamers use clicky switches for strong tactile and audio feedback when they type.

questions_and_answers.question: Are clicky switches mechanical?
questions_and_answers.answer: Clicky switches are one variety of mechanical switches known for their tactility and â€œclicky-clackâ€ sound profile. Contrast this to linear mechanical switches, which feel smooth and are comparatively quiet.

questions_and_answers.question: What is the most clicky switch?
questions_and_answers.answer: The most clicky switches are those with a click bar such as the Kailh Box Whites.

big_picture.desc: offer both pronounced tactile and audio feedback
"clickety-clacks"; like autumn leaves getting stepped on

big_picture.desc: satisfying audio and tactile feedback you get when using them

types.desc: Linear switches are smooth and have a gentle clacky or thocky sound

questions_and_answers.question: What is a linear switch?
questions_and_answers.answer: Linear switches are a type of switch that offers users a smooth and gliding typing feel in contrast to the bump found in tactile switches.

questions_and_answers.question: What are linear switches good for?
questions_and_answers.answer: Linear switches are good for many use cases. Linear switches are good for gaming because of their consistent keystrokes. Linear switches are also good for office work and noise-sensitive environments because of their quietness. Other users like it for its smoothness and clacky or thocky sound profile.

questions_and_answers.question: Are linear switches better?
questions_and_answers.answer: Ultimately, the best switch for you comes down to personal preference. But if you are looking for a buttery smooth typing experience with a subdued sound profile, then linear switches are for you.

questions_and_answers.question: Do linear switches feel weird?
questions_and_answers.answer: Linear switches should not feel weird: they are consistent and smooth. However, if you prefer more tactile feedback when typing, consider tactile and clicky switches.

questions_and_answers.question: Do linear switches click?
questions_and_answers.answer: Linear switches do not click. Instead, expect smooth keystrokes without tactile bumps or clicks.

questions_and_answers.question: Can you type fast with linear switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: You can type fast with linear switches as with any other switch varieties. Once you get accustomed to a switch style, you can type fast on it.

questions_and_answers.question: Are all linear switches good for gaming?
questions_and_answers.answer: Linear switches are great for gaming. Gamers love linear switches for their smooth and consistent keystrokes.

questions_and_answers.question: Why do gamers use linear switches?
questions_and_answers.answer: Gamers use linear switches for their smooth and consistent keystrokes.

questions_and_answers.question: Do linear switches break in?
questions_and_answers.answer: If you feel your linear switches are scratchy, they might still need to break in. You can either break them in through usage over time or you can lube them.

questions_and_answers.question: Are linear switches mechanical?
questions_and_answers.answer: Linear switches are one variety of mechanical switches known for their smooth keystrokes. Contrast this to tactile mechanical switches, which offer a bump in their keystrokes.

big_picture.desc: known for their smooth typing experience
ranges from silent to a medium clack or thock
they are buttery smooth and are also perfect for noise-sensitive environments
